_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, OG Packing and Cold Storage has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 OG Packing and Cold Storage, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that OG Packing and Cold Storage has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name           | Process Chemical          | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Process 1                Anhydrous Ammonia           13,000

Process 2                Anhydrous Ammonia           21,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We

have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



OG Packing and Cold Storage operates a commercial packing and storage facility for cherries and blue berries in Stockton, CA. The facility has two (2) ammonia systems which provide refrigeration capacity to the following:



System 1

(4) Building A Cold Storage Rooms (Room 1, Room 2, Room 5, and Room 6)

(1) Hydrocooler (Line 1)

(2) Chilled Water Pits

(2) Fumigation Rooms



System 2

(4) Building B Cold Storage Rooms

(1) Building B Hallway

(2) Building C/D Packing Rooms

(1) Building E Cold Storage Room

(3) Hydrocoolers (Receiving, Line 2, and Line 3)



The refrigerated zones in Building B, Building C, Building D, Building E, the Chilled Water Pits, and the Fumigation Rooms are equipped with evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation while Building A Rooms 1, 2, 5, and 6 are equipped with evaporators and a pump recirculator as required for pumped overfeed operation. All control valve groups are mounted on the roof (Building B, C, D, and E) or near the high side machinery area (Building A) to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within two (2) refrigeration machinery rooms, (1) outdoor high-side skid, and directly outside near the machinery rooms. A partial list of system components includes:



System 1

(3) High Pressure Receivers

(2) Liquid Recirculators

(2) Flooded Pit Accumulators

(1) Liquid Transfer Vessel

(2) FES Screw Compressors

(2) Vilter Reciprocating Compressors

(5) Evaporative Condensers

(9) McCormack Ceiling Suspend

ed Air-Cooling Evaporators

(5) Bunker-Mounted Air Cooling Evaporators

(1) Hydrocooler (Line 1)



System 2

(1) High Pressure Receiver

(1) Liquid Transfer Vessel Pump

(1) Main Suction Accumulator

(3) FES Screw Compressors

(1) Vilter Screw Compressor

(1) Vilter Reciprocating Compressor

(2) Condensers

(5) Building B Zone Accumulators

(5) Building C/D Zone Accumulators

(1) Building E Zone Accumulator

(10) Building B McCormack Ceiling Suspended Evaporators

(15) Building C/D McCormack Ceiling Suspended Evaporators

(3) Building E McCormack Ceiling Suspended Evaporators

(3) Hydrocoolers (Receiving, Line 2, and Line 3)



System 1 and the flooded portion of System 2 operates as follows: high pressure liquid from a high pressure receiver is piped to each zone or hydrocooler, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator. From the accumulators, cold liquid ammonia is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulators. The ammonia vapor is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to a main suction accumulator. From there, it passes through the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.



System 2 operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receivers is piped through a liquid feed solenoid valve, an expansion valve, and into one of two liquid recirculator. From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each evaporator, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into evaporator.  Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator.  As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which passes through an isolation valve and is returned

to the liquid recirculators. The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculator and the gas is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.



System 1 at OG Packing and Cold Storage was originally building in the 1970's. In 1994, California Controlled Atmosphere was hired to supply and install the refrigeration equipment for System 2 (Building B). In 1997, California Controlled Atmosphere was hired to modify System 2 to provide refrigeration capacity to Building C/D. The system has been modified in numerous other instances since that time. Most recently, APEX was hired in 2014 to replace the System 2 high pressure receiver and APCCO was hired in 2015 to supply and calibrate ammonia sensors for the cold storage rooms.



Each refrigeration system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent ammonia gas to a diffusion tank or atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. Each entrance to a machinery room contains emergency refrigeration shutdown and ventilation controls for use during an emergency situation.

Each ammonia system at OG Packing and Cold Storage consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. The systems are not connected to each other, nor co-located such that a release from one system would impact the ability to operate the other systems. As such, OG Packing and Cold Storage has two (2) refrigeration processes.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous am

monia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



OG Packing and Cold Storage has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration processeses. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration processes at the OG Packing and Cold Storage facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates continuously from spring to early summer, the rest of the year the system continues to run as required to store outside product. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



1.4 Five Year Accident History



OG Packing and Cold Storage has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



OG Packing and Cold Storage's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- Cali

fornia Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



OG Packing and Cold Storage has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, OG Packing and Cold Storage continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved OG Packing and Cold Storage's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that OG Packing and Cold Storage's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



OG Packing and Cold Storage has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, OG Packing and Cold Storage has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For

the future, OG Packing and Cold Storage now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for OG Packing and Cold Storage employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program OG Packing and Cold Storage will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
